results.title: Editing
results.creator_credit: Bruce A. Block, Tim Barr and AIMS Instructional Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Film making techniques”.
Discusses the processes of film editing from the preparation of the work print to the completion of a finished, edited film. Explains the processes of setting up the editing bench, rewinding, using the moviescope, splicing, breaking-down the work print, marking, adding dialogue and using the moviola.

results.title: Editing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Covers cutting on action and in terms of graphics; and by following the shooting of a sequence through to the editing of the final product indicates how editing can serve to expand, compress and rearrange time.

results.title: Editing
results.creator_credit: Mike Crisp, Harris Watts and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On camera: the BBC video production course”.
Two versions of an item about a factory that has introduced morning exercises for its workers. Shows how the same material can be edited in different ways to change the shape of the story. There is also a demonstration of how interviews can be edited to greatest advantage and how shots can be juxtaposed to make the best use of materials.

results.title: Editing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Fundamentals of film making”.
An introduction to editing the newly processed film with examples of the right and wrong way. First extract and discard unwanted material and adjust the general order, then edit to preserve continuity of movement by cutting an action matching action or the use of cut aways; continuity with static subjects and editing to create contrast and impact; importance of tempo.

results.title: Edith Piaf
results.creator_credit: Peter Graham, Theodora Olembert and Triangle Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary on the life of the famous French singer. Highlights the pressures undergone by entertainers, such as the constant travel, drugs and alcohol and media attention. Narrated by Alan Badel

results.title: Edith Head
results.creator_credit: Charlotte Kerr, Christian Blackwood, Sokal-Kerr Productions and Blackwood Productions
results.brief_description: An interview with multi-award winning costume designer Edith Head in which she discusses her career and presents some of the costumes she has designed for Hollywood legends including Mae West, Jean Harlow, Ginger Rogers, Dorothy Lamour, Paul Newman and Robert Redford. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Edge of the World
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Bennett, Don Featherstone and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This program looks at the important role the ocean and deserts of Western Australia have played in shaping Tim Winton’s values and beliefs, and how the natural world continues to nourish his creativity as a writer. He stresses the place of landscape in his writing, and the important role nature plays as a counterbalance to the less attractive elements of modern civilisation. As we watch him fishing, he recounts his fascination with the monastic tradition and with individuals who are able to successfully survive alone and away from civilisation - an interesting comment in light of his 2001 novel, “Dirt music”. The documentary includes scenes acted from his novel “Cloudstreet”, and extracts from “The Riders”, “Shallows” and “Scission”, read both by Tim Winton and Hugo Weaving.
